feed.title: Timothy Olyphant is Justified
feed.subtitle: The actor talks about playing a lawman, getting snubbed by the Golden Globes and returning to Deadwood.

category.term: 0~Timothy Olyphant~Raylan Givens~Hollywood Foreign Press Association~Apple iTunes
category.label: InformQString

link.Abstract: Timothy Olyphant talks about playing a lawman, getting snubbed by the Golden Globes and returning to Deadwood.
link.title: Timothy Olyphant

category.term: 0~Timothy Olyphant~Raylan Givens~Hollywood Foreign Press Association~Apple iTunes
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
By the time he connects with us for our scheduled interview, the news has already reached Timothy Olyphant. That morning, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, following the lead of the Screen Actors Guild the day before, passed him over in the category of Best Actor in a Dramatic Series. This led some, including The Hollywood Reporter, to question why the respective voting bodies snubbed Olyphant and his show, Justified.

"As I understand it, (the HFPA) is 50 people from around the world that make that vote, and I slept with three of them," he deadpans. "I don't know if that helps me or hurts me, but it just shows you it could turn pretty quick.

"Maybe those three are the ones that killed me," he added. "We're not on speaking terms."

Olyphant is calling from the set of the FX series (airing on Super Channel in Canada), which is currently shooting its third season. On the show, he plays the lead, Raylan Givens, an ice-cream-loving, 10-gallon-hat-wearing U.S. marshal whose old-school values and sense of justice lead him back to his hometown of Harlan, Kentucky, after several years spent in the fast-paced world of Miami.

Originally brought to life in the pages of Elmore Leonard's short story, Fire in the Hole, Olyphant's Givens is as handsome and soft-spoken as he is impulsive and dangerous.

"I think there's something interesting about taking a guy who feels like he was born 100 years too late and putting him in a modern world, where the way people govern themselves doesn't seem to make sense with him," the Hawaiian-born, California-raised actor says, "to take, essentially, a cowboy, where everything is black and white and put him in a world where everything seems to be a little fuzzy."

According to Olyphant, most of the credit goes to Leonard, the 86-year-old American author whose books, including Get Shorty, Out of Sight, 3:10 to Yuma, and Rum Punch (which was eventually turned into the 1997 Quentin Tarantino film, Jackie Brown), have cemented themselves in popular culture.

"One of the many things I love about Elmore is that he writes about people that have a pattern of behaviour: They put themselves in the same situation, only to find the exact same outcome. He always does it in a funny, surprising way. He's the coolest mother----er in literature."

Of course, Givens isn't the first lawman Olyphant has played. As Sheriff Seth Bullock on the critically acclaimed HBO series, Deadwood, the actor cemented his place in television history — chaperoning the audience through the operatically seedy underworld of 1800s South Dakota. Lasting three seasons (2004-2006), Deadwood was heralded for ushering in the era of intelligent yet hyper-violent, profanity-filled, and sexually adventurous shows that are now de rigueur for the cable channel.

"I think that, after 9/11, there was a feeling in this country that people felt that their enemies were everywhere and around the corner, and everyone was looking at their neighbours differently, type of feeling," the 43-year-old actor recalls. "That feeling seemed to be very much alive in that show. That capacity for violence was everywhere. So as much as it was about the 1800s, it felt very much like we were doing something contemporary. I know when (creator David) Milch was talking about Hurst, he was practically talking about Murdoch."

It's understandable that, with similar shows such as AMC's Hell on Wheels popping up in its wake, interest in Deadwood has remained high. So much so, that Milch told Esquire magazine recently that he didn't think "the last word has been said on the subject. I still nourish the hope that we're going to get to do a little more work in that area."

If there is a possibility that Deadwood will be resurrected in either television or film format, no one told Olyphant.

"I keep hearing about my future employment through journalists," he says when asked about Milch's quote. "I have no idea (about any future projects) and I've had no conversations about it."

For now, though, his focus is on Justified's Givens.

"That character on Deadwood woke up in the morning and it seemed like killing someone was on his mind, and there was a capacity for violence and an anger in everything that he did. The guy woke up and made some oatmeal and it seemed like he was gonna be killing somebody. That's not what I'm doing on this show," he says of Justified. "I think it's a worthwhile distinction to me."

Even if the Foreign Press or the Actors Guild didn't recognize his efforts this year, Olyphant is still riding a bit of a hot streak. He was nominated for an Emmy (losing to Friday Night Lights' Kyle Chandler) and let's not forget his character's besting of Mad Men's Don Draper as GQ's Most Stylish Man on TV.

"I appreciate being part of the conversation," he says diplomatically. "That's better than someone not bothering you because there was no f---ing way you were gonna be nominated. So that's nice."

source.title: Timothy Olyphant is Justified
